      • doto

        public <R> Stage<R> doto(Function<? super T,? extends Stage<R>> action)
        Description copied from interface: Managed
        Borrow a reference and execute the given action.

        The reference will be released when the action's future is finished:

         
   final Managed<Database> m = ...;

   return m.doto(db -> {
     return db.query(...);
   });
        Specified by:
        doto in interface Managed<T>
        Type Parameters:
        R - the type of the return value from the action
        Parameters:
        action - The action to perform on the borrowed reference.
        Returns:
        The future returned by the action.

      • borrow

        public Borrowed<T> borrow()
        Description copied from interface: Managed
        Borrow the underlying reference.

        This reference must be explicitly released, otherwise the application could leak reference which will cause Managed.stop() to misbehave

        Specified by:
        borrow in interface Managed<T>
        Returns:
        A borrowed reference.

      • isReady

        public boolean isReady()
        Description copied from interface: Managed
        If managed reference is started, but not stopping or stopped.

        Should only be used for diagnostical purposes. Code using references should utilize futures returned by methods like Managed.start() and Managed.stop() to know when there reference is ready.

        Specified by:
        isReady in interface Managed<T>
        Returns:
        true if the underlying reference is constructed, and available to be borrowed.

      • start

        public Stage<Void> start()
        Description copied from interface: Managed
        Start the managed reference.
        Specified by:
        start in interface Managed<T>
        Returns:
        a stage associated with the starting of the managed reference.

      • stop

        public Stage<Void> stop()
        Description copied from interface: Managed
        Stop the underlying managed reference.

        If called multiple times will only A stop call will do the following (in order):

        • subsequent borrowed references are not valid
        • waits for the reference count to become zero, this indicates that no one is using the reference
        • destruct the managed reference
        Specified by:
        stop in interface Managed<T>
        Returns:
        s stage associated with the stopping of the managed reference

        public String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
